title: Hand over one woman to be violated
vignette: Pagans seize a group of women and demand: “Surrender one of you for sexual violation, or we will violate you all.”

options.text: Comply; sacrifice one to spare the many.
Refuse; better all suffer than single out a victim.

title: Surrender the fugitive or the town dies
vignette: Soldiers surround a town and say: “Hand over the named fugitive U. bar Kushav or we kill everyone.”

options.text: Hand him over to save the town.
Refuse; do not sacrifice an individual life.

title: Broken barrel of terumah wine
vignette: Pure terumah wine is leaking into a lower vat of impure non-sacred wine. May one contaminate it by hand to save the valuable lower vat?

options.text: Yes; actively contaminate to avoid large financial loss.
No; let it drip and become impure on its own.

title: Spilled terumah oil on the ground
vignette: A jug of pure terumah oil tips over. Catch it with unclean hands to salvage some, or let it soak into the earth?

options.text: Catch it, though you render it impure.
Do not touch; avoid deliberate defilement.

title: Jar of terumah with doubtful impurity
vignette: Uncertainty arises whether a sealed jar of terumah became impure. Protect it (hide/cover) or leave it exposed and treat as pure?

options.text: Take extra precautions to guard against possible impurity.

title: Feeding terumah fodder to a hired cow
vignette: A priest rents an Israelite’s cow and must feed it. May he give the cow terumah vetches (holy produce)?

options.text: Yes; caretaker may use his priestly food even for another’s animal.
No; terumah should not benefit non-priests’ property.

title: Defiling one loaf to save the rest
vignette: A traveller is carrying several loaves of priestly bread. A bandit says: “Hand me one loaf so I can render it impure, or I’ll contaminate them all.”

options.text: Hand over a single loaf to minimise the loss.
Refuse; better let them all become impure than aid deliberate defilement.

title: Who may glean terumah-produce fields
vignette: Gleanings from a field sown with terumah are available after harvest. May both poor Israelites and poor priests collect them, or only poor priests (to avoid accidental misuse)?

options.text: Allow all poor to glean; they can sell to priests and keep the money.
Restrict gleaning to poor priests to prevent mistakes with holy food.
